cards.front: What are the three parts of the **Cell Theory**?
cards.back: 1. All living things are made of cells. 2. Cells are the basic unit of life. 3. All cells come from pre-existing cells.

cards.front: Who were the scientists credited with developing **Cell Theory**?
What is the function of the **Nucleus**?
cards.back: It acts as the control center of the cell and contains the genetic material (DNA).

cards.front: What do **Mitochondria** do for the cell?
cards.back: They are the 'powerhouse' that convert nutrients (glucose) into energy the cell can use.
Small structures that are responsible for making proteins.
The jelly-like substance that fills the cell and surrounds the organelles.
A network of passageways that carries proteins and other materials from one part of the cell to another.

cards.front: What is the role of the **Golgi Apparatus (Body)**?
cards.back: It receives proteins, packages them, and distributes them to other parts of the cell.

cards.front: Which organelle is responsible for **Photosynthesis** in plants?
How do **Vacuoles** differ in plant vs. animal cells?
cards.back: Plant cells have one large central vacuole for water storage; animal cells have several smaller ones.

cards.front: What is the function of the **Cell Wall**?
cards.back: A rigid outer layer found only in plants (and some fungi/bacteria) that provides support and protection.
They contain chemicals that break down food particles and old cell parts (the 'cleanup crew').

cards.front: What are the main differences between **Prokaryotic** and **Eukaryotic** cells?
cards.back: Prokaryotes (like bacteria) have no nucleus; Eukaryotes (like plant/animal cells) have a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles.

cards.front: Which two organelles are found in **plant cells** but NOT animal cells?
